list.title: Question 1
list.content: The system of equations given below represents three planes in space. $$ \begin{aligned} x + 5z &= 2 \\[6pt] -2x + y - 6z &= -1 \\[6pt] 2y + 8z &= 6\end{aligned} $$ - Show that this system of equations has an infinite number of solutions. [3] - Find the parametric equations of the line of intersection of the three planes. [3]
list.markScheme:
- If we convert the given system of equations into an augmented
matrix, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4a910b72-19e4-4a42-a75f-d3d95dad3499/images/d7ebb5d4-b295-4302-9567-a2e1473a7ad9/e92843ccd123af5e4a99f63d9b0726fa3e606968.svg)


  Hence, using the method of Gaussian Elimination, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4a910b72-19e4-4a42-a75f-d3d95dad3499/images/033e32bc-f2d9-4a59-9060-bff7fcf72d3d/e2d7661b43a236c006ef48f0c2b01b8969087034.svg)


  The last row of zeros tells us that the system is consistent. As there are only two pivot positions corresponding to $x$ and $y$, the variable $z$ is free. Hence the system has an infinite number of solutions.
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4a910b72-19e4-4a42-a75f-d3d95dad3499/images/a24bb1ff-e239-489e-9468-bac7261a87fe/9e7ed3301e98f940e211c9d9825320385d1b6446.svg)


  If we express $x$ and $y$ in term of $z = t$, we obtain $x = 2 - 5t$
and $y = 3 - 4t$.
  Hence the parametric equations of the line of intersection of the
$3$ planes are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{x = 2-5t,\hspace{0.5em}y = 3-4t,\hspace{0.5em}z = t}\end{aligned}
  $$

  where $t \in \mathbb{R}$.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
The system of equations given below represents three planes in space.

$$
\begin{aligned}
x + 2y - 2z &= 4 \\[6pt]
3x + 5y - 4z &= 9 \hspace{3em} [\text{where $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$}] \\[6pt]
\hspace{8em} 4x + 6y + az &= b\end{aligned}
$$

Find the set of values of
$a$ and $b$ such that the three planes have no points of
intersection.
list.markScheme:
If we convert the given system of equations into an augmented matrix, we
have
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1eff31cd-f81a-40d3-a9a0-352d3b8d40cd/images/56c50794-cd49-4a04-a686-f984e87d7a77/a778d4ec606218beb371bd39dc87b29995594e1e.svg)


Hence, using the method of Gaussian Elimination (row reduction), we get
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1eff31cd-f81a-40d3-a9a0-352d3b8d40cd/images/773571c8-bc12-4ee1-b737-609f22b4a75a/6253468268c59bd2ef1a8710c34fc0674230f053.svg)


Therefore, the three planes have no points of intersection if
$\answer{a = -4 \text{ \& } b \neq 10}$

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
The system of equations given below represents three planes in space.

$$
\begin{aligned}
x - 3y + 2z &= 5 \\[6pt]
3x + 5y + az &= b \hspace{3em} [\text{where $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$}] \\[6pt]
\hspace{8em} 4x + 2y - 3z &= 7\end{aligned}
$$

Find the set of values of
$a$ and $b$ such that the three planes have exactly one intersection
point.
list.markScheme:
If we convert the given system of equations into an augmented matrix, we
have
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7a77c3e0-720f-4e8e-b1f0-3a1a566969f5/images/6b98681b-5126-465b-b888-037d41e7ac5a/80fc0ab3f375c653f4f6b65da0848111f53434b1.svg)


Hence, using the method of Gaussian Elimination (row reduction), we get
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7a77c3e0-720f-4e8e-b1f0-3a1a566969f5/images/f1854f11-59b0-4c8e-9c56-f85434ffd329/4d136862891148012690049e8033042f467da733.svg)


The three planes have exactly one intersection point if
$\answer{a \neq -5 \text{  \&  } b \in \mathbb{R}}$

list.title: Question 4
list.content: Consider the following system of equations: $$ \begin{aligned} x - 3z &= -2 \\[6pt] -3x + y + 6z &= 3 \\[6pt] 2x - 2y + (a-4)z &= b-3\end{aligned} $$ where $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find conditions on $a$ and $b$ for which - the system has no solutions; - the system has only one solution; - the system has an infinite number of solutions. [6] - In the case where the number of solutions is infinite, find the general solution of the system of equations in Cartesian form. [3]
list.markScheme:
- If we convert the given system of equations into an augmented
matrix, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/337a6bb3-6a0b-43b9-94ae-f6b3e3e2e231/images/8d98a020-29c7-478a-a0bb-6bf878fd5365/fc1722646826b747a78d8a717d7f3e24269c7335.svg)


  Hence, using the method of Gaussian Elimination, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/337a6bb3-6a0b-43b9-94ae-f6b3e3e2e231/images/31a4e0fb-271e-49aa-a81e-3bd96631488b/d5e5b20529826e7a89602916ebcc5c019737e1ea.svg)


  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/337a6bb3-6a0b-43b9-94ae-f6b3e3e2e231/images/bf77797d-a060-4bd4-9a53-e06213ae845f/846a88889458337ab2aeba1c647b2fdea4de2812.svg)


  The system has no solutions if
  
  - $\answer{a = 4 \text{ and } b \neq 5}$

  The system has only one solution if
  
  - $\answer{a \neq 4 \text{ and } b \in \mathbb{R}}$

  The system has an infinite number of solutions if
  
  - $\answer{a = 4 \text{ and } b = 5}$

- For $a = 4$ and $b = 5$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/337a6bb3-6a0b-43b9-94ae-f6b3e3e2e231/images/e3231ca7-c35c-4f15-a847-afac67f27a47/8dacc6559227ad5fef6e1aeaeb78b17ac463976c.svg)


  Hence the general solution of the system of equations in Cartesian
form is

  $$
  \answer{\dfrac{x + 2}{3} = \dfrac{y + 3}{3} = z}
  $$

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Consider the following system of equations: $$ \begin{aligned} x + y + 4z &= 1 \\[6pt] 3x + 2y + 16z &= 5 \\[6pt] 4x + 2y + (a-1)z &= b-4\end{aligned} $$ where $a,b \in \mathbb{R}$. - Find conditions on $a$ and $b$ for which - the system has no solutions; - the system has only one solution; - the system has an infinite number of solutions. [6] - In the case where the number of solutions is infinite, find the general solution of the system of equations in Cartesian form. [3]
list.markScheme:
- If we convert the given system of equations into an augmented
matrix, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d8715397-fddc-47af-a086-22a4cee1a437/images/5638940f-c801-4755-8b7d-52ae2b81766d/71754659bebe16a79ad946ef4aafc3d04e0565c7.svg)


  Hence, using the method of Gaussian Elimination, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d8715397-fddc-47af-a086-22a4cee1a437/images/cb906fce-0828-4c2b-84ae-93973ebbdb34/038e3e50a616d564956e685040a3632159834164.svg)


  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d8715397-fddc-47af-a086-22a4cee1a437/images/068d63d4-4bbe-4375-b74d-bf683839e578/87fa5baaa0e247b59e3412d3ed2d320e73681f15.svg)


  
  - The system has no solutions if
$\answer{a = 25 \text{ and } b \neq 12}$
  - The system has only one solution if
$\answer{a \neq 25 \text{ and } b \in \mathbb{R}}$
  - The system has an infinite number of solutions if
$\answer{a = 25 \text{ and } b = 12}$

- For $a = 25$ and $b = 12$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d8715397-fddc-47af-a086-22a4cee1a437/images/a07b136b-b0df-49ac-ba53-56744d53d569/6539968a8c5ba7b87ecfd3a27ed70dbb2c225401.svg)


  Using the method of back-substitution, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -y + 4z &= 2 \\[6pt]
  y &= 4z - 2 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x + (4z - 2) + 4z &= 1 \\[6pt]
  x &= 3 - 8z \hspace{4em}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the general solution
of the system of equations in Cartesian form is

  $$
  \answer{\dfrac{3-x}{8} = \dfrac{y + 2}{4} = z}
  $$

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Consider the following system of equations: $$ \begin{aligned} x + y + z &= -1 \\[6pt] 4x + 2y + z &= 3 \\[6pt] 9x + 3y &= p\end{aligned} $$ where $p \in \mathbb{R}$. - Show that this system does not have a unique solution for any value of $p$. [4] - - Determine the value of $p$ for which the system is consistent. - For this value of $p$, find the general solution of the system. [4]
list.markScheme:
- If we convert the given system of equations into an augmented
matrix, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1940aa5a-fa4d-4186-9d5a-8ac99127c963/images/f0382b32-b21c-4ba1-a0f5-4a79c36ddd6f/9f7fa9719e458a709cb1464a249710dcc108a8a6.svg)


  Hence, using the method of Gaussian Elimination, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1940aa5a-fa4d-4186-9d5a-8ac99127c963/images/bc6d005c-16b0-433a-b016-6a14a5666e85/ba6fbb5338a0222b47ef58fe6256b45e3ba64074.svg)


  If $p \neq 12$, the system is inconsistent and has no solutions. For otherwise, the~system is consistent and $z$ is a free variable. Hence, for any given value of $p$, the system either has no solutions or it has infinite number of solutions.
- 
  - $\answer{p = 12}$
  - For $p = 12$, we have
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1940aa5a-fa4d-4186-9d5a-8ac99127c963/images/c2f1ebf4-8bb7-48ae-a3f9-7516a74cb2b0/bd86febfa147c1cf21b65e965d8b671ce0dbd029.svg)


    Letting $z = t$ and using the method of back-substitution, we
obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    -2y - 3z &= 7 \\[11pt]
    -2y - 3t &= 7 \\[5pt]
    y &= -\dfrac{7}{2} - \dfrac{3t}{2}\end{aligned}
    $$

    and

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x + y + z &= -1 \\[5pt]
    x +\left[-\dfrac{7}{2} - \dfrac{3t}{2}\right] + t &= -1 \\[1pt]
    x &= \dfrac{5}{2} + \dfrac{t}{2} \hspace{5.5em}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the general solution of the system in parametric form is

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &\answer{x = \dfrac{5}{2} + \dfrac{t}{2}, \hspace{0.5em} y = -\dfrac{7}{2} - \dfrac{3t}{2}, \hspace{0.5em} z = t}\end{aligned}
    $$

    where $t \in \mathbb{R}$.

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Consider three planes represented by the following system of equations: $$ \begin{align*} \Pi_1: -2x + ay + 4z &= 2 \\[6pt] \Pi_2: x + by - 2z &= -1 \\[6pt] \Pi_3: 2x - y + cz &= 3 \end{align*} $$ Where $a,b,c \in \mathbb{R}$. - State the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$ for which - The system has infinite solutions. - The system is inconsistent. [7] - In the case where the system has infinite solutions, describe the geometric relationship between the three planes. [2] - In the case where the system is inconsistent, identify one of the geometric relationships that could exist between the three planes. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we convert the given system of equations into an augmented matrix, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e8f9c4b4-8442-45bf-8389-6c5abb138ec8/images/3f804c21-6625-4b1d-a6cc-56f4ed650a1e/aa1012a.PNG)


  Hence, using the method of Gaussian Elimination, we get
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e8f9c4b4-8442-45bf-8389-6c5abb138ec8/images/da6543cf-8657-43e1-8040-dec0d15cf8cf/aa1012b.PNG)


  
  - From row 2, if the system has infinite solutions, we must have $a + 2b = 0$.
    This implies that if $a = -2b$, there are infinite solutions to the system.
    However, we also note from row 3, that if $a - 1 = 0$ and $c + 4 = 0$, then the system is inconsistent. In this case we have $a = 1$ and $c = -4$.
    There are infinite solutions to the system if $a = -2b$, $c \in \mathbb{R}$ unless $a=1$, $b=-0.5$ and $c=-4$.
  - As noted in part (i), if $a = 1$ and $c = -4$, the system is inconsistent.
    However, we also note that if $a \neq 1$ and $c = -4$, Gaussian Elimination leads to
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e8f9c4b4-8442-45bf-8389-6c5abb138ec8/images/7cd78d6b-425a-48e9-b2b6-e41b3b6fdb70/aa1021b.png)


    In this case, we can also have an inconsistent system.
    From part (a), if $a = -2b$ then the system is consistent (has infinite solutions), however consider when $a \neq -2b$.
    It follows that $a+2b =k$, where $k \neq 0$, this leads to
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e8f9c4b4-8442-45bf-8389-6c5abb138ec8/images/757dcf45-e7bd-4832-b55b-c311d8f0a8d8/aa1012a2.png)


    Using row 2

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    ky &=0 \\
    \intertext{As $k \neq 0$ then}
    y &= 0 
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Using row 3, this value of $y$ shows an inconsistency as shown below.

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    (a-1)y &=5 \\
    (a-1)\times0 &= 5 \\
    0 &= 5 
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence...
    $\answer{\text{The system is inconsistent if } a = 1 \text{ and } c = -4, b \in \mathbb{R} \text{ or if } a \neq 1, a \neq -2b \text{ and } c = -4.}$

- From (a) (i), we note that $\Pi_1$ is a multiple of $\Pi_2$. They are therefore equations representing the same plane.
  $\answer{\Pi_1 \text{ and } \Pi_2 \text{ are coincidental, }\Pi_3 \text{ intersects both planes in a straight line.}}$
- In total there are 4 different geometric realtionships between the planes when the system is inconsistent.
  First, from part (a) (i) we note that the system is inconsistent if $a=1$, $b=-0.5$ and $c=-4$. In this case,
  $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\Pi_1 \text{ and } \Pi_2 \text{ are coincidental and } \Pi_3 \text{ is parallel to both planes.}}\hspace{0.525em}$
  Second, from (a) (ii), we have one scenario where $a=1$, $b \neq -0.5$ and $c=-4$. In this case,
  $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\Pi_1 \text{ and } \Pi_3 \text{ are parallel and } \Pi_2 \text{ intersects both planes.}}\hspace{0.525em}$
  Thirdly, if $a \neq 1$, $b=-0.5$ and $c=-4$,
  $\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\Pi_2 \text{ and } \Pi_3 \text{ are parallel and } \Pi_1 \text{ intersects both planes.}}\hspace{0.525em}$
  Finally, if $a \neq 1$, $a \neq -2b$ and $c=-4$, then $\Pi_1$ intersects $\Pi_2$ on a line, $\Pi_1$ intersects $\Pi_3$ on a different line and $\Pi_2$ intersects $\Pi_3$ on another different line. Additionally,$\hspace{0.525em}\tcbhighmath{\text{All three of these lines of intersection are parallel.}}\hspace{0.525em}$
